body:
> It repeated opens and closes a Stata window. After a while, it opens a prompt saying that "The kernel appears to have died."

The most likely issue is that you need to register the type library. See [here](https://kylebarron.github.io/stata_kernel/getting_started/#prerequisites) under "Windows specific steps".
I've tried that but it didn't work out. I still have the busy status on notebooks and Stata window flashing.

Can you open the anaconda terminal and then type `jupyter notebook` into that terminal? It should open Jupyter Notebook just like before, but then any error messages will be printed to the terminal. Copy and paste those error messages here.
You should be able to just type "Anaconda terminal" into the search bar and it'll be the first result.

`
(base) C:\>jupyter notebook
[I 13:24:30.441 NotebookApp] The port 8888 is already in use, trying another por
t.
[I 13:24:30.699 NotebookApp] JupyterLab extension loaded from C:\ProgramData\Ana
conda3\lib\site-packages\jupyterlab
[I 13:24:30.699 NotebookApp] JupyterLab application directory is C:\ProgramData\
Anaconda3\share\jupyter\lab
[I 13:24:30.707 NotebookApp] Serving notebooks from local directory: C:\
[I 13:24:30.707 NotebookApp] The Jupyter Notebook is running at:
[I 13:24:30.707 NotebookApp] http://localhost:8889/?token=864880f6da049e589f6af2
b1fd0acc06f8b9012b5ac978a3
[I 13:24:30.707 NotebookApp] Use Control-C to stop this server and shut down all
 kernels (twice to skip confirmation).
[C 13:24:30.989 NotebookApp]

    Copy/paste this URL into your browser when you connect for the first time,
    to login with a token:
        http://localhost:8889/?token=864880f6da049e589f6af2b1fd0acc06f8b9012b5ac
978a3
[I 13:24:31.518 NotebookApp] Accepting one-time-token-authenticated connection f
rom ::1
`

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44911489/50020419-e1550e00-ffa3-11e8-98ce-93e415e6752d.png)

Now I get this when I try to open a Stata kernel notebook
So Jupyter Notebook should have opened in your web browser. Now try opening a Stata notebook. If it fails, it'll print error messages to the same terminal.

`
(base) C:\>jupyter notebook
[I 13:24:30.441 NotebookApp] The port 8888 is already in use, trying another por
t.
[I 13:24:30.699 NotebookApp] JupyterLab extension loaded from C:\ProgramData\Ana
conda3\lib\site-packages\jupyterlab
[I 13:24:30.699 NotebookApp] JupyterLab application directory is C:\ProgramData\
Anaconda3\share\jupyter\lab
[I 13:24:30.707 NotebookApp] Serving notebooks from local directory: C:\

[I 13:24:30.707 NotebookApp] http://localhost:8889/?token=864880f6da049e589f6af2
b1fd0acc06f8b9012b5ac978a3
[I 13:24:30.707 NotebookApp] Use Control-C to stop this server and shut down all
 kernels (twice to skip confirmation).
[C 13:24:30.989 NotebookApp]

    Copy/paste this URL into your browser when you connect for the first time,
    to login with a token:
        http://localhost:8889/?token=864880f6da049e589f6af2b1fd0acc06f8b9012b5ac
978a3
[I 13:24:31.518 NotebookApp] Accepting one-time-token-authenticated connection f
rom ::1
[I 13:26:11.836 NotebookApp] Creating new notebook in
[W 13:26:12.161 NotebookApp] 403 POST /api/contents (::1): Permission denied: Un
titled.ipynb
[W 13:26:12.162 NotebookApp] Permission denied: Untitled.ipynb
[W 13:26:12.163 NotebookApp] 403 POST /api/contents (::1) 328.00ms referer=http:
//localhost:8889/tree
`
Do you get the same error if you try to open a Python notebook?
Yes.
Right now, even though no notebooks are open. Stata window still continues to flash open and close.

It doesn't seem to be a core issue with Stata Kernel. I think when you installed Anaconda, you checked "Install for all users" instead of "install for just me". That looks like it created a permissions problem for Jupyter. 

Try this:
1. Uninstall Anaconda. Run the program at `C:\ProgramData\Ana
conda3\Uninstall-Anaconda3.exe`.
2. Install Anaconda again, checking "Install for just me" on the install screen.
3. Install `stata_kernel` again
I have uninstalled Anaconda, and reinstalled with "Install for just me". And re-installed `stata_kernel`. But the issue remains.
Are you able to open a Python notebook now?

python notebook works. but the stata kernel does not

Thanks. Now we got to the Stata kernel issue. Can you attach the file
```
C:\Users\vargac10\.stata_kernel_cache\console_debug.log
```

```
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

      name:  stata_kernel_log

       log:  C:\Users\vargac10\.stata_kernel_cache\log0.log

  log type:  text

 opened on:  14 Dec 2018, 15:02:46

adopath + `"C:\Users\vargac10\AppData\Local\Continuum\anaconda3\Lib\site-packages\stata_kernel\ado"'

r; t=0.00 15:02:46

```
[console_debug.log](https://github.com/kylebarron/stata_kernel/files/2681583/console_debug.log)

The reason it's not working is because you have `rmsg` turned on permanently. In a separate Stata session, run
```stata
set rmsg off, permanently
```

This is still a bug that I should fix, but I think the above should be a short term solution for you.

rename.to: Kernel won't start with rmsg on

body:
It worked! I turned rmsg off, permanently

Thanks!
